quotes.quote: PaperÂ is more patient than man.
Blank paper always symbolizes the anxiety of the painter.
PaperÂ is to write things down that we need to remember. Our brains are used to think.
To put what you see on paper is the same as funneling what you feel through yourself as a performer.
So often is the virgin sheet ofÂ paperÂ more real than what one has to say, and so often one regrets having marred it.
PaperÂ acts as an eraser on the mind, as soon as you look at what you've written.
Anything onÂ paperÂ is obsolete.
A blank piece ofÂ paperÂ is God's way of telling us how hard it is to be God.
I speak to theÂ paper, as I speak to the first person I meet.
This paper will no doubt be found interesting by those who take an interest in it.
A piece of paper doesn't make you a pastor any more than making predictions makes you a prophet.
But onÂ paper, things can live forever. OnÂ paper, a butterfly never dies.
PaperÂ remains the standard to which digital media can only aspire.
It is in front of the theÂ paperÂ that the artist creates himself.
If they give you ruledÂ paper, write the other way.
A blank page ofÂ paperÂ and a pen is the greatest invention its so exciting to be confronted by possibility.
A piece ofÂ paperÂ makes you an officer, a radio makes you a commander.
PaperÂ isn't important. It's the words on them that are important.
Fill yourÂ paperÂ with the breathings of your heart.
Who knew paper and ink could be so vicious.
It's curious how easy it is to tell a piece ofÂ paperÂ what you don't dare say to someone's face.
Only on paper has humanity yet achieved glory, beauty, truth, knowledge, virtue, and abiding love.
PaperÂ is poverty. It is only the ghost of money, and not money itself.
A piece of paper or a photograph is as much an object, or as 'material' as a ton of lead.
PublishedÂ papers may omit important steps and the memory of men of science, even the greatest, is sadly fallible.
Behind every piece ofÂ paperÂ lies a human situation.
TheÂ paperÂ is patient, but the reader is not.
In the surface of theÂ paperÂ there is only length and width-there is no such thing as thickness.
When the weight of theÂ paperÂ equals the weight of the airplane, only then you can go flying.
The four walls ofÂ paperÂ are like a prison because every idea wants to spring out in all directions - everything is connected with everything else, sometimes more than others.
